name: Hyperphosphatemic Familial Tumoral Calcinosis
chief_complaint: Painful, hard lumps under my skin and in my joints
physical_findings: Restricted range of motion in affected joints
Possible erythema or ulceration over larger deposits
treatment: Topical sodium thiosulfate for ulcerated lesions
Surgical excision of severely symptomatic deposits
Trial of acetazolamide for select patients
prognosis: Chronic progressive course with significant morbidity but normal lifespan. Early intervention may slow progression of calcifications.
description: A rare autosomal recessive disorder of phosphate metabolism caused by mutations in FGF23, GALNT3, or KLOTHO genes. Characterized by ectopic calcifications in soft tissues and hyperphosphatemia due to renal phosphate wasting. Calcifications typically develop in periarticular regions and may cause severe functional impairment.
